III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Policy and procedures
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12503
Section • (2) The policies and procedures must cover at least all the
Description following areas:
1

• (a) Eligibility requirements for youth to participate in
the program.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Leadership would only allow placement consideration of a
transgender youth at an all-male program. The male is biologically
male but identifies as female.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on December 19,
2024. Complainant stated they had no additional information.
Former Chief Administrator was interviewed via telephone on
December 20, 2024. She stated she was terminated late
afternoon on Friday, December 13, 2024. Just prior to her
termination she stated she was made aware of an email that
President sent regarding Youth A. Youth A had been a youth at
Queen of Angels and a referral was made to Holy Cross ILP
program. Youth A is biologically male but identifies as female and
sought placement at the agency’s female IL house. Former Chief
Administrator stated PAFC Administrative Assistant inquired to her
regarding how to proceed with the referral because Youth A wants
to go to female program and President responded by saying since
youth is a male he needs to go to a male IL house. Former Chief
Administrator reported agency practice for transgender youth is to
interview youth for both homes and where youth feel most
comfortable. Both Fayette IL home and Corcoran IL home have
rooms with an attached bathroom, so they are able to
accommodate gender identity and where the youth feels more
comfortable. Former Chief Administrator clarified she was told
about the existence of the email chain but does not have access
to it. She stated agency policy is written in a way that outlines
youth preference is accommodated. She is aware because she
wrote the policy based on licensing rules and DHS policy.
PAFC Administrative Assistant (PAFC AA) was interviewed
via telephone on January 2, 2025. She stated there is a
scheduled interview today with Youth A to determine if she would
be appropriate for placement in their independent living home.
This interview was rescheduled from December 16, 2024. She
stated Youth A wanted to be placed in Corcoran which is their
female home, but they are not able to place in the female program
but did not elaborate on the reason. She asked the DHS Foster
Care worker (DHS FCW) if they would consider King House which
is their all-male independent living program.
2

DHS Foster Care worker (DHS FCW) was interviewed via
telephone on January 27, 2025. She stated she is the assigned
foster care worker for Youth A since youth entered care in October
2024. Youth is biologically male but identifies as female. She
stated she participated in an interview with Youth A and Holy
Cross for potential placement in a female independent living
facility on January 2, 2025. The interview is regarding potential
placement at Holy Cross King House which she believed at the
time was their female house, but later learned is a male IL house.
It had been rescheduled from December 16, 2024. She stated the
interview went well. Holy Cross gave an overview of the program
and rules. Youth A inquired about viewing the home and was told
by Holy Cross staff that could occur if she was accepted into the
program but didn’t appear very open to Youth A viewing the home.
DHS FCW stated after the interview Holy Cross immediately sent
her an email indicating Youth A would not be accepted into the
program because of a past criminal charge for CSC. DHS FCW
expressed confusion as to why Holy Cross didn’t relay that would
have been a barrier for Youth A being accepted into the program
prior to the interview. She stated other agencies have denied
Youth A for the same reason and since the interview there was
another agency that has accepted Youth A into an independent
living program. DHS FCW stated she has been present with Youth
A during independent living interviews. Youth A does not have a
phone.
Documents reviewed
• MISACWIS case file for Youth A that included a December
16, 2024, social work contact: An independent living
interview with Holy Cross was scheduled for 12/16/24 via
teams. The interview had to be rescheduled due to the fact
that Youth A was not made available for the meeting. The
foster parents were sent several reminders of the interview
and failed to log on. DHHS will reschedule the interview at
a later time.
• January 2, 2025, denial email from Holy Cross to DHS
FCW. “Thank you for your recent referral to King House ILP
program located in Clinton Township. After interviewing
Youth A, we are unable to accept him at this time.
Contributing factors supporting this decision are listed as
follows: explosive behaviors, CSC charge, and sexually
acting out behaviors.”
• December 11, 2024, email from President to agency staff.
“I spoke with licensing. Youth A should not be interviewing
at Corcoran at this time”.
3

• Holy Cross Independent Living Plus Program
Description. Independent Living Plus (ILP) is a program
where youth/young adults, live in a communal living setting
called “Staff Supported Housing” or in a family like setting
with a “Host Home Provider”. The main goal of the ILP
program is to help youth/young adult transition successfully
out of the foster care system by teaching the necessary life
skills to become functional independent adults. The
program provides supervised living environments that help
youth/young adults build relationships based upon the
values of respect and helping others by being honest,
trustworthy individuals. Youth/young adults can remain in
the program for up to one year without the approval of an
exception request.
Locations:
King House – Mt. Clemens Michigan: Serving youth who
are biologically male
Fayette House – Saginaw, Michigan: Serving youth who are
biologically male
Corcoran House -Mt. Morris, Michigan: Serving youth who
are biologically female
• Independent Living Plus eligibility requirements:
Youth/Young adults who meet the following qualifications
would be deemed appropriate for Independent Living Plus:
• Ages 16 to 19 with an open abuse and neglect case
and or juvenile justice case
• Leaving residential who cannot return home
• Cannot be placed into a family foster home
• Where adoption is not planned
• Demonstrates a capacity for and willingness to learn
independent living skills while in a supervised, structured
ILP program prior to transitioning into another living
arrangement
• Self-motivated and demonstrate selfcare potential.
Examples of self-care potential would be the youth showing
they are responsible for getting themselves up in the
morning for school, taking public transportation to school or
work, managing their own medications and taking as
prescribed, and having the ability to resolve conflicts in a
healthy manner
4

• Live in either the Staff Supportive Housing or with an
HCS approved Host Home Provider.
• Denial Criteria: Denial criteria is based upon the
youth/young adults’ inability to show evidence of self-care
potential or refusal of services. Below is a list of examples
that may result in denial of placement or request for
removal from placement.
• Assaultive behavior towards another person, be it
another youth/young adult in the program or staff
• Inability to manage their medications and activities of
daily living
• Recent AWOL attempts and/or current AWOL status
• Attempts of harm self
• Theft and/or destruction of property owned by others
or program property
• Possession of illegal substances and weapons
• Continued refusal to accept help towards treatment
goals, and/or disrupting the treatment of other clients
• Refusal to pay rent
• ILP Eligibility Scaling: Tier 1, Tier 2, Tier 3. Tool that
measures several areas to determine if youth is appropriate
for ILP program. Score 0-15: appropriate, 16-29: consideration
with discussion, and 30-42: not appropriate. Eligibility scaling
for Youth A shows a score of 38.
Analysis The agency is found to be in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of documentation, the agency interviewed
Youth A for potential placement in King House which is for
biologically male youth. Youth A preferred placement in a female
home and both Youth A and DHS FCW believed King House was
for female youth, however the interview for potential placement in
the biologically male IL home is consistent with the information in
the agency Independent Living Plus program description.
Technical Assistance
Clarify in IL program description IL eligibility scale use and
admission criteria.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
